150467996.review:
For such a simple game of run-and-kill, one wouldn't imagine its sequel to be any more interesting or complex.  Enter Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number, which not only comes with a deeper story than its predecessor, but with a much more diverse soundtrack, and newer characters with unique gimmicks.

Set within an alternate 1980s Florida, Wrong Number revolves around a series of morally-questionable protagonists who are either hunting down a truth, or finding means to sate their bloodlust.  The sharper controls help with the more complex missions, and if you're coming fresh off Hotline 1, it can seem a little daunting with the more unusual characters, but the game never asks more than what your keyboard demands.

Some character highlights include:
- A brother-and-sister duo controlled simultaneous with gun and chainsaw
- A journalist who refuses to use guns
- An experienced soldier on a stealth mission

The soundtrack also takes a huge leap in quality, and while it's all still the same retrowave feel of the first game, the variety of moods the OST brings is far stronger to give each character their own unique voice in their separate scenarios.  If you haven't played Hotline 1 yet, consider that a tutorial if you get it on sale.  Otherwise, Wrong Number is the stronger game, and Hotline 1 has such little story within it, that you can safely skip the first game to enjoy its sequel.

150385464.review:
Alright, alright, I got around to this game way late. But, it's timeless.

Coming off of the first game, Hotline Miami 2 throws you an offscreen curveball by suddenly focusing the combat on gunplay and less on just beating people up with whatever's laying around. It was immediately 5 times more frustrating than the first game and I almost got tired of it... because I was used to 1. 

But then I got used to planning out my attack lines. Picking up the right weapon for each room. Prioritizing certain targets. It got to be totally awesome.

Except there's no satisfaction to the story. It's a beautifully weird and completely disconnected set of details that somehow comes together in the end and I love it for that reason. I love the new characters and I love how it all ties together, but... it just hurts. 

People complain about how basic the game is and the quality of life things that just aren't there, and the constant cheesing enemies through doors. I get it! But it's an artistic experience and it's really fun except for the few times it isn't, and even then you love it anyways. 

I don't give objective ratings based on subjective preference because that's dumb. But I say give this one a try.

Oh and this game convinced me to watch Bojack Horseman for some reason

150334220.review:
-PROS-

• Great story. It takes the ground work the first game setup and expands upon it. The characters are like-able, their stories are unique and interesting and they did a REALLY good job of tying everything together and wrapping everything up.
• Graphics are consistent with the first game and are still good looking for retro style
• The soundtrack is great and stays consistent with the previous game. I would even go as far as to say this game's sound track is superior in some ways.
• The variety of characters adds variety to completing levels and offers different choices based on your personal play style
• Progressive difficulty really ramps up the challenge more so than the first game. The training wheels come off much quicker in this one.

-CONS-

• The doors are still a broken, buggy mess. You would think having 2.5 years between the first game and this one that they would have focused on getting them fixed. Expect gunfire to fail to penetrate the doors, fail to penetrate past door frames, melee attacks failing to hit when in or through a door frame, your character phasing through doors and enemies teleporting through doors/walls to kill you in 1-hit.
• Dogs can turn door knobs and open doors
• The detective characters do not have service pistols/firearms for some reason? So you start their levels with nothing
• Apparently in the 80's our military didn't have ballistic/bulletproof vests or helmets being deployed behind enemy lines
• Bugs out the wazoo. Enemy A.I. will have seizures occasionally, get stuck in walls and on 2 separate occasions I became stuck or stuck in a wall and needed an enemy to find me with a gun to kill me to progress.
• You can drop/throw weapons out of bounds or past invisible walls, which can sometimes instantly result in a failed level because you have nothing to defend yourself with. You shouldn't be able to throw weapons in unreachable locations.
• Scenarios are RNG at times because the spawns change seemingly at random occasionally so beware of that
• 1v1 melee combat is also at times RNG on you winning the fight. Basically if the game gives you the dice roll on a swing against the enemy swinging at the same time.
• Some levels cannot be completed with certain masks unless it's possible to bug/glitch encounters. They did not balance the masks in this game to be usable in all levels.
• The characters you play know what kind of scenarios they are getting into and choose to go into them empty handed during certain levels even if you procure a gun in a previous level at full ammo capacity to take with you.
• Expect to get killed off-screen by enemies you cannot see in just about every level and countless rage inducing trial and error processes to map out where all of the enemies are or their general vicinity.

-CONCLUSION-

5/10

This is a game that exists and is a faithful sequel to the original. I enjoyed getting through with the game and the final level was a treat for me personally. The story is superior in every way to the first game and so is the soundtrack. If it wasn't for those 2 pros specifically, I would have given this a 3/10. I still recommend if you can look past all the things that don't make sense and it being riddled with bugs. If you played the first game like I did, then you will likely enjoy it. $15 isn't a bad price, but I would suggest getting it on sale.

150010309.review:
(SPOILER WARNING)

Hotline Miami 2 is an under-rated masterpiece of a game. It prides itself on its top-down one hit die mechanic, and it flourishes. Despite dying being a punishment, it never feels like it. Mainly for the reason that through every death, you actively become better and better, following a specific rhythm, and its not drawn out because all you have to do is hit "R" once. I do have my gripes with the game, such as it not expanding on jackets story, and you never really have a chance to enjoy the characters and get attached to them because of how little you play as them before their inevitable death throughout the story. As mush as i enjoyed that said story, it's incredibly difficult to learn it by yourself, and you'll always end up having to search up a youtube video abt it. That aside, however, the game play itself is ball dropping. It always has you on your toes, and stressed, and the violence is great.

It's a rather short experience, but if you have the money: BUY IT!!!!

149709349.review:
Es la primera vez que hago este tipo de reseñas pero, este juego se lo merece.
[h2]NOTA: NO HAY SPOILERS PERO MI CONSEJO ES QUE, ANTES QUE ESTE JUEGO, PRUEBES EL HOTLINE MIAMI 1.[/h2]
Hotline Miami 2, en pocas palabras, es más del primero, pero mejor.
Es por ello que, antes de que gastes en este juego, prueba con el primero ya que (al menos en mi caso tras volver a jugar el primero) los controles se sienten un poco más lentos, dando una mejora quizás no tan notable comparado con su predecesor pero, una vez que vuelves a jugarlo, se siente esa diferencia (por más mínima que sea).
Eso respecto al gameplay, que no voy a ondear más a detalle más allá de que, resulta ser muy entretenido y la música es un perfecto acompañante. (Nota: Una vez que termina una canción, se vuelve a repetir; por lo que, si estás estancado en un nivel, la música puede un poco ser estresante si es una melodía que no sea del 100% de tu agrado y, aunque nunca lo hice con este juego, puedes escuchar música por otro medio; lo importante es que disfrutes el juego). Para terminar con este aspecto, me encanta la rapidez con la que puedes reiniciar un nivel, ¿perdiste ni bien comenzar? Solo presiona R y, mientras la música no se detiene por más que mueras, sigue intentando.

En cuanto a su historia es, algo raro de explicar, no porque sea una trama cinematográfica con un millón de fumadas ni nada, solo que, por decirlo de alguna forma, tienes 2 puntos de vista; me explico:
Este videojuego es considerado como una crítica a la violencia en los videojuegos, es muy sangriento a pesar de ser solo pixeles, y satisface 2 partes bien diferenciadas de los jugadores: Los que buscan jugar un momento (como lo es mi caso por falta de tiempo) y, los que se encargan de revisar detalles de la historia y a partir de ahí construirla, tomar en cuenta cada punto y diálogo.
Cuando acabé los dos videojuegos, no había entendido mucho; sin embargo, tras ver un video en youtube, me di cuenta que la historia era muy interesante y sentí que no había disfrutado de lo que tiene por ofrecer (lógicamente esto porque no le di el tiempo que se merece, actualmente re-juego un nivel como si fuera una partida rápida o intento sacar la A+ en algún nivel), esto en un principio, me desanimaba un poco porque sentía que jugaba por jugar aunque, tras entender el por qué de esta decisión, pues simplemente lo acepté. Ojo, esto no implica que no sea disfrutable el juego, solo que, si eres alguien que busca una historia clara y no quiere adentrarse demasiado o, como es mi caso, no juega muy seguido y se olvida de detalles, pues sinceramente (y sin faltar el respeto a esta obra) quizás no sea el videojuego que buscas, aunque no soy quién para decidir por ti.

Un detallito que se me pasó por alto es el editor de niveles, que si bien aún no lo he probado, he visto niveles que, a simple vista, son muy llamativos (Es como Geometry Dash, pero en menor medida).

Entonces, ¿Deberías jugar este videojuego?
Un rotundo sí, no es como "Tienes que jugar este videojuego antes de morir", pero verdaderamente vale la pena, su gameplay se basa en seguir intentando y la banda sonora es buenísima, sus colores son brillantes y muy de los 80's, la época que se ambienta es bastante atractiva, y todo el tema de las mafias rusas y las llamadas telefónicas resulta ser muy interesante.
Mi consejo es que lo compres cuando este en oferta (no porque pagar lo que vale regularmente no valga la pena, solo que; algo se vuelve mejor si lo pillas más barato xd). Si eres alguien que le gusta el gameplay frenético y que no tiene mucho tiempo, este juego te puede divertir y, si por el otro lado, eres alguien que quiere profundizar en la historia y puedes recordar detalles, o juegas muy seguido, también es para ti; la historia no es una obra cinematográfica al nivel de El Padrino, Metal Gear Solid, The Last of Us o los Backyardingans, pero es buenísima y resulta interesante descubrir cada detalle como jugador, sientes la revelación y ves si tus sospechas eran ciertas o no. 
Al final del día, es tu decisión, no soy quién para decidir por ti, pero, espero que te sirva de ayuda (si alguien lee todo esto. si no mejor lo hago video en youtube xd).
Si te decides en comprarlo solo diré:
[h2]DISFRÚTALO A TU MANERA.[/h2]

149671243.review:
Hotline Miami 2 is misunderstood. I feel like a lot of people miss out on certain themes either from just not caring or being too ignorant to comment on them and will thus call stuff they don't like "convoluted" or "pretentious" or "thinking it's way smarter than it actually is." Insults like that always come across to me as projection, and here it's no different.

Hotline Miami 2 not only comments on certain concepts in its own world, but in a genius way offers a meta idea with each of these concepts. The fans are obviously representative of the people who loved Hotline Miami 1 and wanted more of the violence, action, power trips, and insanity in that game. The henchman represents the more human aspect of the enemies, and also tells the player that these pixel enemies are actual people in their own world. The question of how we process and look at violence in video games and other forms of media is everywhere here. And the developers actually take it a step further and shows you what constant escalation of violence leads to. For that, you'll have to play the game for yourself and either be alert to the subtle world building and underlying messages here.

Now onto the gameplay. If you liked Hotline Miami 1 this is essentially more of the same. Super addicting, super violent, and super fast paced. I've seen some people call these levels bad because they're difficult, but I strongly disagree. For starters, the more difficult levels they're referring to actually have a narrative reason for being so difficult. You try raiding a f*cking nuclear power plant with a squad of 4 soldiers, knowing that the military is expecting you to die and is only sending you because you're expendable. Or try getting revenge on a different mafia family that took advantage of the fact that you were so targeted by the main character in the first game. To me, the added difficulty is appreciated and makes a lot of sense. Plus, let's be real it's not like any of this is impossible. You can get through this game in like 5 hours if you just use some strategy ffs.  

The presentation is incredible, so much so that I can't think of many games that can pull it off so effortlessly as the Hotline Miami games. The soundtrack is superb all the way through, the visuals are fun, vibrant, and chaotic, and there's some really nice imagery. My favorite example of this imagery would have to be Richard and his role as a foreshadow of death. It's really quality stuff that is hard to not love.

Overall, this game is mostly what you'd expect: Hotline Miami 2. But it takes the first game and greatly increases the scope of everything. I don't know which one I like more, but they're both classic games that you should play.

149544374.review:
Jacket AND Biker have been reduced to freaking background characters. Hotline Miami does not feel the same without a playable Jacket or Biker. It's like having a Super Mario game without Mario and Luigi. 

Characters aside, playing HM2 feels more like a slog. The level design is the biggest problem, with unrealistically large, open spaces full of enemies that have infinite sight range. The melee weapons seem more unreliable in HM2 than in HM1. But the worst problem has to be the buggy dogs, which have not been fixed (in fact, they might be worse). They can get you through doors without even seeing you first. Overall, HM2 is more painful than fun.

If you are an aesthetics person who appreciates fun instead of pointless pain through means of escapism, just stick to Hotline Miami 1. If anything, you should only get Hotline Miami 2 for the level editor. But credit where credit is due, the premium edition of Hotline Miami 2 does give you one of the best things in Payday 2...

I loved Hotline Miami because I could pick my own play-style. I could burst through a door with a gun and start redecorating with blood or I can sneak around smacking people with no exposure. "More of the same but different" is what this sounds like and I wish they did. Stay with one character so we can have a bond with them, give us more weapon variety, and a better overarching story.

148850180.review:
Si en la anterior reseña comenté que Hotline Miami no se hace pesado de jugar no puedo decir lo mismo para su secuela, que me hizo dar mas de un puñetazo a la mesa de mi escritorio y mas de un grito de rabia tras morir injustamente por enésima vez.

En términos generales no hay gran diferencia entre las dos entregas, ya que ambos juegos consisten en una serie de niveles cuyo objetivo será únicamente acabar con todos los enemigos mientras suena música electrónica de fondo. Sin embargo ninguno de los cambios añadidos me han gustado, salvo quizás el mayor énfasis en la trama contando con diferentes personajes jugables, algunos de los cuales tienen relevancia en la primera entrega aunque sigue siendo muy abstracta, al menos para mí. En este caso en lugar de contar con un único personaje con diferentes habilidades según la máscara que porte contaremos con diferentes avatares según el nivel con variaciones desbloqueables.

Los niveles son mas grandes y complejos, lo que podría parecer algo bueno pero conlleva un gran problema: la distancia de visión. En algunos niveles se incluyen pasillos con enemigos que no podemos ver por la longitud del mismo y obliga a disparar de lejos para abatirlos de casualidad o arriesgarnos a atravesar el nivel a ciegas lo que exige una rapidísima velocidad de reacción. A parte de esto, algunos niveles son demasiado largos y difíciles haciendo desesperante el terminarlo.

Wrong Number sigue siendo un juego divertido pero que no llega a la calidad de su antecesor, además de ser mas repetitivo e injusto en comparación.

148621129.review:
Much like the first game this is a 10/10. However this ISN'T the first game and if you go in expecting the same thing (very likely) it will feel more like a 6/10 until you learn to appreciate it. 
The gameplay is different, the characters are different and unique, instead of having 1 character being the jack of all trades you have a bunch of them each with their own Harvard degree, the gunplay is different and much more required yet the guns are shittier and slower
The difficulty is through the roof and the hard mode is a cruel twist on what a "hard" entails turning the bullshit up to 11 as is common with this game
The story is trippier and more convoluted than the first yet reveals so much more if you get to understand it.
This game is multiple times harder as a media to consume compared to the first on pretty much all fronts but it's as many times more rewarding and immersive. By the time you get good enough at it to find it appropriate in difficulty your most hated levels will have become you favorite and your least favorite character will have something you miss when playing the rest.
It's a masterpiece you have to suffer through until you get to love it.

The gameplay is just as tight and rewarding as before, if not moreso. I love the variety in gameplay that the player is given, lots of special conditions for certain characters that makes the game feel very replayable.

The storyline is much more up front and center with HLM2 compared to the first game, but I found it to be a very very enjoyable experience. Lots of questions that were asked in the first game get answered, or expanded upon in this game.

I missed out on the internet's discussions of this game and I was very saddened to hear that this game was at one point maligned amongst its former fans. This game feels like a complete love letter to everything that made Hotline Miami 1 such a fun and engaging experience. This game touches my heart in a way that HLM1 can't quite. It's hard to explain but its very comfortable if very bleak.
Please give this game a fair try, its one of my favorites.

147612230.review:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number - это игра, которая заставляет меня задавать вопросы о смысле бытия. Как тупое красно-синее пятно на холсте абстракционизма, эта игра вводит в заблуждение своим названием и коварно обманывает ожидания игроков. Сначала вы чувствуете себя как безумный наемник, убивая врагов в огне и ярости. Но затем, как мистическое пробуждение, игра резко переключается на рассказ о том, как улитки властвуют над вселенной.

Представьте себе, что вы находитесь в мире, где улитки - это главные архитекторы всего сущего. Они строят гигантские крошечные домики, используя спагетти вместо кирпичей и сметану вместо цемента. Вы начинаете понимать, что ваша задача - помочь улиткам в их странных приключениях, и, находясь под влиянием этой абсурдной концепции, вы начинаете задавать вопросы о своем собственном существовании.

Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number - это как путешествие в безумие, где вы перестаете верить своим глазам и начинаете размышлять о том, что на самом деле означает быть улиткой в мире, наполненном спагетти и сметаной. Возможно, это гениальное произведение искусства, или, возможно, просто странный сон, который вы видите после того, как слишком много поели перед сном. Кто знает? Возможно, ответы на эти вопросы лежат в самой глубине вашей души, ждут, когда вы решите покорить этот безумный мир улиток и сметаны.

147443523.review:
Hotline Miami 2 es como su primera entrega, pero más ampliada, con workshop con nuevos mapas y finalmente, sus sprites no están deformes, su soundtrack supera por mucho al del primero y tiene una gran variedad de personajes jugables en comparación al primer juego. Tiene más niveles, con la misma o aún más rejugabilidad, sus nuevas mecánicas son cuanto menos interesantes, ejemplo de esto son Alex y Ash que poseen dos personajes en uno o Corey con su giro (que dudo que alguien con suficiente inteligencia quiera usarlo), las cuales le añaden un toque de refrescura al juego.

Pros: A comparación de la primera entrega, Hotline Miami 2 posee mayor cantidad de niveles, más personajes jugables y un soundtrack más extenso con más artistas y frecuencias, tiene una historia más comprensible (Aún que seguro necesitaras visitar paginas de guías o vídeos para comprenderla del todo), y su gameplay, se siente más rico, con más movilidad, más satisfacción al matar y con mayor variedad de enemigos y los niveles, son más extensos. Para esta segunda entrega, los de Dennaton Games prefirieron que la puntuación se quede mayormente en el combo, decisión que al principio si bien, no estaba demasiado feliz con escucharlo, a medida que lo fui jugando, descubrí que en verdad, era muy enriquecedor, manteniendote pegado a la pantalla de la pc, dándole al juego más tensión de que puedas perder el combo y mayor satisfacción al terminar el nivel y ver que todo tu esfuerzo te dio una merecida S en el rango final.

Contras: 
Alabo este juego con toda mi alma, lo que Hotline Miami hacía mal, en este juego lo agarraron y lo cambiaron abruptamente, mejorando y cambiando en una manera positiva, por ejemplo, los sprites del primer juego que estaban deformes, cambiaron, sin muchas o nulas deformidades a la vista. Me fue imposible encontrarle una contra a este juego que no fuera que su duración es corta.
9.5/10

Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number lleva todo lo que hizo que el primer juego fuera una experiencia única y lo lleva al siguiente nivel. La serie sigue siendo un ejemplo de audacia y originalidad en la industria de los videojuegos. El juego mantiene la jugabilidad frenética y desafiante de su predecesor, pero expande aún más las posibilidades. La variedad de personajes jugables y sus habilidades únicas agrega una capa adicional de profundidad estratégica. Cada nivel sigue siendo un rompecabezas mortal que debes resolver con precisión y rapidez.

La música y el estilo visual continúan siendo un punto fuerte en esta secuela. La elección de la música y la forma en que se sincroniza con la acción en pantalla es impresionante y crea una experiencia auditiva y visual envolvente. La narrativa, aunque compleja, sigue siendo intrigante y teje una historia apasionante a través de múltiples perspectivas.

Sin embargo, Hotline Miami 2 no está exento de críticas. Algunos jugadores han encontrado que la dificultad es desafiante en exceso, lo que puede llevar a momentos frustrantes. Además, la historia puede ser confusa en ocasiones debido a su estructura no lineal y la cantidad de personajes.

Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number es un juego que lleva la experiencia de su predecesor, Hotline Miami, a un nivel completamente nuevo y emocionante. Este juego de acción indie, desarrollado por Dennaton Games, continúa con la fórmula de acción rápida y brutal que hizo que su predecesor fuera un éxito, pero agrega una profundidad adicional a la historia y la jugabilidad que lo hace aún más atractivo.

Una de las características más notables de Hotline Miami 2 es su estilo visual y sonoro. El juego se desarrolla en una versión alternativa y retorcida de los años 80, y esto se refleja perfectamente en su estética retro y su fantástica banda sonora llena de sintetizadores y música electrónica. Cada nivel está meticulosamente diseñado para crear una experiencia visual y auditiva inmersiva que te sumerge por completo en su mundo.

En cuanto a la jugabilidad, Hotline Miami 2 mantiene el enfoque en la acción rápida y letal que caracterizó a la primera entrega. Cada nivel es un rompecabezas de violencia en el que debes planificar tus movimientos con cuidado, aprovechar las armas y objetos disponibles, y aprender de tus errores para superar a los enemigos. La dificultad del juego es alta, pero la satisfacción de superar cada desafío es aún mayor.

Lo que realmente destaca en Hotline Miami 2 es su narrativa. La historia es compleja ya menudo desconcertante, pero está llena de giros sorprendentes y momentos impactantes que mantienen tu interés en todo momento. La trama se desarrolla a través de múltiples personajes jugables, cada uno con su propia perspectiva y experiencia, lo que agrega una capa adicional de profundidad a la historia.

En resumen, Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number es una secuela que cumple y supera las expectativas. Combina una estética retro impresionante con una jugabilidad adictiva y una narrativa intrigante. Si disfrutaste del primer juego o eres fanático de los juegos indie con un toque único, definitivamente deberías darle una oportunidad a esta obra maestra. Es un viaje salvaje y emocionante que te mantendrá pegado a la pantalla de principio a fin.

"Hotline Miami" - A Violent and Visually Striking Masterpiece

"Hotline Miami" is a video game that has captivated gamers since its release, and for good reason. This indie gem, developed by Dennaton Games and published by Devolver Digital, is a neon-soaked, adrenaline-pumping experience that leaves an indelible mark on players. Its unique blend of style, gameplay, and narrative makes it a true standout in the gaming world.

One of the game's most striking features is its aesthetic. "Hotline Miami" transports players to a grimy, 1980s Miami dripping with neon lights and pulsating with a synthwave soundtrack. The pixel art style, while seemingly simplistic, is a work of art in itself, creating a visually mesmerizing experience. This distinctive style doesn't just serve as eye candy; it enhances the game's atmosphere, drawing players into its gritty, neon-soaked world.

But "Hotline Miami" isn't just about looks; it's about gameplay, and it delivers in spades. The core of the game revolves around fast-paced, top-down combat that demands precision and strategy. Each level is a puzzle of sorts, with enemies, weapons, and obstacles to navigate. The beauty of "Hotline Miami" lies in its unforgiving nature - one hit kills, and death is a constant companion. This forces players to think on their feet, plan their moves carefully, and execute with flawless precision. The satisfaction of clearing a room full of foes with a perfectly executed sequence of actions is unparalleled.

The soundtrack deserves special mention. Composed by artists such as Perturbator and M.O.O.N., the music is an integral part of the game's experience. The synth-heavy tracks not only complement the 1980s setting but also drive the gameplay. The music ebbs and flows with the action, intensifying as the player enters dangerous situations, creating a heart-pounding, immersive experience.

Storytelling in "Hotline Miami" is intentionally enigmatic and surreal, leaving players to decipher its meaning. As the protagonist, Jacket, players receive mysterious phone calls instructing them to carry out brutal assassinations. The narrative is a puzzle, inviting players to piece together the fragments and draw their conclusions. It's a unique storytelling approach that adds depth and intrigue to the game.

"Hotline Miami" isn't without its controversies, as its extreme violence and themes have sparked debates about the impact of video game content. However, it's essential to view it as a form of artistic expression, pushing boundaries and challenging conventions.

In conclusion, "Hotline Miami" is a great game because it successfully blends its striking visual style, adrenaline-pumping gameplay, and enigmatic narrative into an unforgettable experience. It's a game that challenges players, not just in terms of reflexes but also in terms of interpretation. While it may not be for everyone due to its intense violence, it undeniably stands as a testament to the artistic potential of video games and continues to be a beloved title among gamers. If you haven't experienced the neon-soaked insanity of "Hotline Miami" yet, it's high time you pick up the phone and dive into this gaming masterpiece.

146383599.review:
[b]Intense mood and intense violence.[/b]

This is only recommended for those who've played the first game, as it expands a lot more upon its story and gameplay. Many may prefer the first game though for its simplicity in both.

The game has a lot of stories going on, taking place both before and after the first game, featuring loads of protagonists, telling why they're going on their own killing sprees. The protagonist of the first game even makes many story appearances, but most everyone probably won't recognize him at first because he never talks, and the pixel graphics were never detailed enough to make him look distinguishable.
The stories constantly jump from past to future and everywhere in between, and its lore goes pretty deep, so it's probably recommended to just look all this up on your own.

I went for the highest rank on all the levels on the game's Hard mode, and doing so only highlighted for me how actually terribly broken this game is. I think most people don't notice its broken nature due to them being blinded by its naturally high difficulty. In other words, on top of the game being already hard, there's a lot of B.S. as well.
While a lot of people seem to not like it, the stages are now larger and more gun-focused, which the idea in and of itself isn't necessarily bad, but the game wasn't designed for that.
The original game always had the character at the center of the screen, no matter how large or small the level was. However, in this game, there are plenty of times where the character can now touch the edges of the screen, but because the game was designed with the character being in the center at all times, the mouse cursor ends up moving along with the character while the screen stays still, making aiming with a mouse really awkward and annoying.
Also, as a result of these large stages, you're now more than likely to die from an enemy's gunshot that's off-screen, strongly encouraging you to constantly hold the shift key to see far-off enemies at all times and straining your pinky finger in the process. Even worse is when dealing with enemies that are above or below the game screen because their extremely high detection range seems to be designed with them being on the horizontal side of a 16:9 monitor, so enemies on the vertical side will more than often shoot you before they're even visible on-screen.
They changed how weapon pick-ups worked, which is already really annoying to deal with, but in doing so, they also seem to have broken something. The order you pick up a weapon is now determined by when they dropped, so even if you wanted the knife that you're standing on, you'll actually pick up the nearby empty shotgun instead simply because the empty shotgun was dropped first, and then you die because you thought you picked up the knife as an enemy runs to you. I think as a result of this new mechanic, there's a chance that you just won't pick up a different weapon on the ground at all. I've had many instances where I tried to pick up a weapon out of the three on the ground, but I only kept grabbing two of the three. Sometimes, a weapon just won't get picked up at all no matter how many times I keep pressing the grab button even if it's the only weapon near me, and only until I position my character slightly differently do I pick it up.
This game also has the same problems the first game had with its RNG enemy spawns, AI, and busted door mechanics. If you're going for high scores and big ranks, then you're at the absolute mercy of said RNG enemy spawns, AI, and busted door mechanics like in the first game, though all that is a lot more prominent here with its larger levels. You fire off a shot to lure an enemy, but they don't hear it even though that exact enemy did last time. You try to lure an enemy out of a room with your presence, but they turn around and shoot you in 3 frames even though they followed you outside the last time you did that. Enemies you thought stayed in a room, for some reason, went outside upon a restart, then stayed in the room upon another restart, still stayed upon another restart, moved outside upon another restart, stayed upon another, and so on. I've read people say that the randomized A.I. is intentional just for the sake of surprising you. It probably makes playing the game casually a little more enjoyable, though it hardly matters at all if you're just patient with your peeking and baiting, but going for proper high scores where you don't have the luxury of being patient is an absolute nightmare with that.

What the game has going for it is its overall vibe and story. Its music is as amazing as ever and its multiple stories are very interesting if you can follow along.
The actual gameplay is absolutely busted. Just because someone can beat a game and get extremely high scores or whatever on it doesn't mean the gameplay is automatically good.

145356146.review: I'll admit, I didn't get the hype when I first started playing, seeing as I hadn't played the first game yet. It seemed like your run-of-the-mill top-down shooter, albeit with a cool aesthetic. But about an hour into the game, I became utterly addicted, and I couldn't leave my keyboard. Was I getting my ass kicked? Absolutely. But with that, I didn't feel the rage towards the difficulty that I did with other games. I was always ready to give it another go. Not to mention that the story is so engaging, and the commentary on sensationalizing these kinds of atrocities and becoming desensitized to violence is beautifully executed. And as if all the twists, turns, and expectation subversion throughout the game wasn't enough, the existential dread of the ending really kicked me in the gut. This is not a game you're going to feel happy-go-lucky playing. You're going to feel exhilarated when you finally beat that level that you've been stuck on for hours, yeah, but the game is primarily going to make you think and feel melancholic. Nevertheless, I love this game and I look forward to playing it over and over again.

145337953.review:
We REALLY need a sideway thumb, because while this game is in fact good, there were several elements I don't like at all, especially for a game like this.

My problems go beyond the mere "Oh the story is a mess and there are too many characters", but it's true I couldn't help but compare to the first; the lack of options you have per levels is a shame, because while I've heard that the Masks' effects were just thrown in per obligation due to Devolver, they still added a new dimension to the game, by having different playstyles, as crazy as it may sound I had fun playing through the entire game with inverted controls (Nigel Mask), but in HM2, at most you only get 4 starting options, and they are exclusive to these characters' levels, and they have at most 4.  I don't know what I'm asking for here, maybe some NG+ thing (it kinda does though) where you can use any playstyles on any levels, but at most I had wished to have the possibility to do a Challenge Run like I could for all of HM1.

Also, Evan Wright's gameplay is completely broken, I hate him for it; it's not that it's bothersome I can't use ranged weapons for the most part, on the contrary it's a welcome playstyle where you can neutralize enemies peacefully, such as depleting the enemies' ammo which can extend your Combo and you can even move while doing so as you get closer to your next targets, but his said Combo system is where the problem lies, because when you get on top of an enemy, you can knock him out with only two punches, but either it gives you the Points and increase your Combo or not at all, you can see why this is annoying because me trying to get the best possible score is entirely based on how the game feels at that very moment, and it goes for every single characters he knocks out in this fashion, so you're bound to see this problem.  There is a way to go around this if you simply want A+ or S Rank; if you actually "try" to punch a third time, but not go through with it (Evan will visibly hold himself back), well that somehow gives you Points and the Combo again, but... it would be possible too to get the Points and Combo from simply knocking him out with two punches, then get them again by trying to do a third punch anyway.

So at most, every enemies as Evan can give you x2 to your Combo, make it x3 if they were holding a gun, but that's also the problem, it's never guaranteed that, even by playing expertly, you will ever get the Max possible Combo + Score in any of his levels, this isn't Dead Ahead where anybody could get it up to x90 with enough practice, because again knocking them out doesn't always gives you the Points Combo, and that's a risk that goes for every single guy you get on top of.  This is so stupid, honestly I would've loved Evan as his gameplay is the most unique and technical out of all the other characters because he doesn't just brute force his way in and he has two more ways to extend his Combos, but this is completely ruined for the aforementioned reasons, and so as an example of why this is hell, I kept having to restart Level 5 because he just couldn't get the full x6 Combo I wanted from the first 2 guys, again this is entirely based on luck if I get it or not, and this is a game you should know you die a lot in, so... have fun rerolling the dies for another 12!  Being a Score Attack game, I believe this randomness is inexcusable.

Now for sure, there are only negatives so far, but these inconsistencies are mostly exclusive to Evan, otherwise everything else works pretty much as it should, and in fact, HM2 introduces a few weirdass playstyles that I can appreciate, like Alex & Ash, and aside from that, the level design, graphics, musics, punishing deaths, it's still what Hotline Miami does best, there's so much going on and there aren't that many games as highly punishing as this, it's pretty fun when you push through all the adversity.  Even when you die many times, you just restart right away, no reloading bullshit... well, aside from the transitions I'd wish to skip; I had to restart Level 4 a few times and I kinda had to sit through quite a few annoying transitions.

I must say though that the Camera is quite a problem in this game, which I'm not exactly talking about visibility issues, but it's about keeping the characters in the center of the screen at all times, because when they're always in that same position, then you will always have an idea of where you're aiming, regardless of what the hell is happening.  At most, there was only ONE Level where Jacket in the first game wasn't perfectly aligned to the center at all times, otherwise though the levels were always floating in these weirdly pleasing colorful voids and the Devs didn't seemed to care about that, but HM2 has several levels where certain Areas are locked to the corners and you will have to approach the edges wether it's to continue fighting or to proceed, which means that aiming with the mouse is going to be a bit confusing at times as it breaks that seamless gameplay I was talking about as you'll need to find your Crosshair somewhere within the white or colorful pixels, it happened several times too many where I lost track of where I was aiming as I have to keep moving, in a game where time is key for keeping your Combo.  Even if you may try to compensate for being at the edge of the screen by aiming in a particular way like across a corridor, by going away from said edge, your aiming doesn't always align with what you were trying to do.  It's weird to explain, and I even feel weird having to explain it, but this is another problem where the gameplay isn't always consistent, especially when coming from HM1, and again while HM1 was only a one-off offender, HM2 has only made it several times worse as the buildings you're going through are oftentimes so large.

The story, I didn't dig all that much, and I also read the comics to try to make more sense out of it; it is weird as the continuity is all over the place and it switches through a ton of characters, personally I may prefer a more concise/focused story, but that in itself doesn't make the game any worse or anything, even HM1 has this "Canon Vs. Non-Canon" shit that I found mildly annoying to grasp, so I guess it's in line with the series, and HM2 does have a few moments where it uses the intertwined storylines to its advantage.  I'll just say this is more about personal tastes even if it did some cool things.

But yeah, IDK what to make of this one, it's still a well made game, but there's Evan which baffles me as to how he got away with his broken Combo System, it's annoying I kept losing my Score because I couldn't see my cursor due to the screen almost never keeping me in the middle now, and there's a tad bit less possible replayability than HM1, but again it can be fun just to go through and there's the Level Editor if you want more, that's always a plus.  I don't think I would like coming back to this one all that much, even if again it's well made, there were just a few too many things that bothered me.  I don't know, I'm perplexed.

145106814.review:
I have yet to 100% this game yet, but so far I can say that this is game has held some of the most rewarding yet brutally challenging experiences I've been through in a game. Everything in this game is turned up a huge notch from the original, as levels are bigger and nerve-wrackingly difficult to survive, the soundtrack is pure ear candy, and the base levels are incredibly replayable alongside the unofficial user-made levels, all of this being tied together by an intriguing and bold narrative that shook me to my core upon understanding it. While not as accessible to play as the original game, it's not trying to be, and it serves to strengthen the messages the game is trying to convey to you. 

Certainly not for everyone, but I highly recommend giving this game a chance if you have played the original, and if you haven't, play it, and come back to this title again.

145073034.review:
I prefer HM1 but HM2 is okay. If neutral was a thing I would most likely choose that.
I want to preface that I only beaten the game once blindly and only the story.

Levels feel wayyyyyyyy too overdrawn. Compared to 1 where everything feels 'snappy', 2 is to the point I feel like i'm being dragged a crossed the pavement. This applies to many elements to HM2, dying feels agonizing. I can die 1000 times over in HM1 and feel agitated but motivated to keep at it because everything is so short. 2 on the other hand, If i die on one segment and stay there for [X] amount of time, knowing that there is another segment right after, really frustrates me to no end. I feel like HM1 has at best, 2-3 segments per level while HM2 has up to like 6-8. WHY? That's way too much. I just want to wear a mask, kill everyone quickly and leave quickly. That's how it felt in HM1, in the sequel it feels like i'm in a never ending shootout where any mistake i make in one segment would push me back nearly 20-30mins of progress. And there's like 6-8 segments on some levels, so keep that in mind. I know I'm not good, I play very casually, but you can spike HM1 difficulty x20000 and see me die 100000x times but at least the segments are short, so it would still be tolerable. /rant

The story is cool and the beginning really shows you that this game isn't child friendly. Its dark, its gruesome, its bloody and thats how it should be. Its a messed up world in a messed up universe and even though the story doesn't seem really coherent it was an enjoyable experience.

Music is good, infact, i would debate its even better than HM1 in terms of music selection. Maybe I'm biased but Roller Mobster is goated, Thanks Carpenter Brut. 

So overall, good music, interesting story, way too dragged out segments on singular levels. I may need to see HM2 gameplay in a different mindset because it's just ain't there chief.

144830563.review:
Played 1 and 2 for the first time ever, while both are great, I prefer this one by a long shot. This is one of those games where you can play the campaign over and over without getting bored. I believe it is to do with the scoring system because it makes you want to better your combos each time. The characters are great, more variety than the first and the music is so much better as well. Playing the game multiple times will make you start piecing together parts of the story so if you only play it once, you might be lost .
   
    The controls are great as usual and the game itself is pretty challenging at times, you will die a lot but it doesn't bother me like in most games where you die  a lot since the levels are that long. Think of this game like a puzzle at times, you have rooms of enemies and you have to approach encounters different ways or maybe certain ways to get through all of them. There are a good amount of weapons and the melee is fun too.

    Post game, the real meat is the level editor. With the vast amount of user created levels, this bumps up the replay value incredibly high. Some people have made lengthy campaigns that pretty much match the length of the main game and the stuff people create is pretty awesome. I've been downloading one by one, all the most popular and high rated levels and campaigns and so far it has added 30+ hours after I beat the main game. That isn't even scratching the surface. I highly recommend this game, it is just too much fun and addicting!

hotline miami 2: wrong number is a top-down shooter that was developed by dennaton games and published by devolver digital. it released in march of 2015 on PC, PS3, PS4, and the vita, with a nintendo switch port coming in 2019 and a port released on the xbox one in 2020. dennaton games is a indie dev whose first game was the first hotline miami game that released in 2012. this is not only the sequel to that game, but also the developer's second game ever as well. additionally, devolver is one of my favorite publishers, as usually any game with them publishing is worth playing in my opinion. i've completed/reviewed a handful of games published by them already, and hotline miami 2 is no different in that it's an simply amazing game that is overlooked if you're only looking for AAA titles from huge companies with giant budgets. 

the sequel plays similarly to the first game, only expanded upon. there's also almost twice as many 'levels' in the sequel compared to the first one. there's also thirteen playable characters compared to only two in the original. there's also a hard mode that is unlocked after beating the game for the first time, making enemies tougher, reduced ammo on all weapons, and things like auto-lock turned off automatically. a level editor was added in around a year later as well, with custom levels being published onto the steam workshop. visually, there are tons of great neon visuals, just like the first game, and as far as audio design goes, again like the first game there is another banger soundtrack with intense techno music. the gameplay itself features crisp controls and mechanics leading to great gameplay loops that makes every level satisfying once you finally beat it without getting killed.

hotline miami 2 is a surprisingly expanded upon sequel to what was an already outstanding game that i loved. it's extremely stylish aesthetic is entertaining even before you factor in the open ended gameplay and engrossing story. there's high replay-value, even with poor AI that can be easy to defeat even on hard mode, and tons of unique little features that keep the game from becoming frustrating. add in the fact that you can buy hotline miami 2 on sale for 85% off, making it only $2.24 is the cherry on top of everything i've already described. i highly recommend waiting for a sale and buying it then, as even rushing through the story only once will still take a solid 6-8 hours depending on your skill level. most people will probably spend 10+ hours, while completionists are taking 30+ hours easily.

144658835.review:
Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is an absolute masterpiece that takes everything we loved about the original game and cranks it up to eleven. From its pulsating soundtrack to its relentless, heart-pounding gameplay, this sequel is a worthy successor that keeps the adrenaline pumping from start to finish.

One of the most striking aspects of Hotline Miami 2 is its commitment to pushing the boundaries of storytelling in video games. The narrative weaves a complex and gripping tale, filled with intriguing characters and unexpected twists. It's a dark, thought-provoking journey that delves into the psyche of its characters, forcing players to question their own morality along the way. The game's non-linear storytelling adds depth and replayability, encouraging you to explore different paths and perspectives.

But it's the gameplay that truly shines. The fast-paced, neon-soaked action is as exhilarating as ever, and the level design is a masterclass in creating challenging and addictive gameplay. Each level is a carefully crafted puzzle of violence, requiring precision, strategy, and lightning-fast reflexes. The feeling of satisfaction when you finally execute a perfect run is unmatched in the gaming world.

The soundtrack, composed by various artists, is an auditory masterpiece. The synth-heavy, retro-inspired tunes perfectly complement the game's frenetic pace, immersing you in its gritty, 1980s-inspired world. The music isn't just a background feature; it's an integral part of the experience that enhances the game's atmosphere and intensity.

Hotline Miami 2 also introduces a diverse roster of playable characters, each with their own unique abilities and playstyles. This variety adds a layer of depth and replayability as you experiment with different approaches to the game's challenges.

Despite its intense difficulty, Hotline Miami 2 never feels unfair. Every death is a learning experience, and the feeling of improvement as you inch closer to mastering each level is incredibly rewarding. This game demands your best and rewards you with a sense of accomplishment that few other titles can match.

In conclusion, Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is a triumph of game design, storytelling, and style. It's a game that will have you hooked from the first beat drop and keep you coming back for more, long after you've completed the main story. If you crave a gaming experience that challenges your skills, engages your mind, and immerses you in a world of neon-soaked chaos, then Hotline Miami 2 is an absolute must-play. It's a thrilling, pulse-pounding masterpiece that stands as a shining example of what video games can achieve as an art form.

Anyways TLDR 8/10 still worth it to waste my time to achieve genocide.

143617688.review:
Hotline Miami is the sort of game you're either going to get incredibly frustrated at because you struggle at it, or the sort of game you'll simply phase into the zone, forgetting reality itself as time basically vanishes ahead of you. 

Personally, it has been and remains one of my favourite games of all time. The gameplay while difficult is rewarding and the sequel, aka. the one I'm reviewing does many things much better than the first one. First, it brings variety to the game play. You won't be able to select your mask on every chapters like in the first game, instead you'll be introduced to multiple characters, each telling their very own story and eventually interacting with each others. The story can be quite confusing at times, but keeping track of what is happening should not be an issue. 

As for the variety these characters bring? A character in particular is a journalist, with whom you'll do pacifists runs (or not the game doesn't prevent you from beating the shit out of anyone but it does slow you down). Another one is in the vietnam, you won't be able to pick guns off of the floor and will have limited ammo, forcing you to be strategic on the way you eliminate your opponents. Then of course, you'll have a few fellas with goofy animals mask which will allow you to choose which mask you'll play with, granting certain perks depending on your choice of drip.

Finally, let's get to the most important part: The music. The reason this game is such a gem is due to its OST, the gameplay and its core mechanics are simple yet polished but that isn't what drives the game. What drives Hotline miami is the pure chaos massacre you go driven by some of the greatest OSTs in indie games history.

To sum everything up, this game might not be something you'll be able to finish. Maybe at some point you'll be stuck due to its difficulty. However, get into it with the mindset that your goal is to get as far as possible, one level at a time. Eventually, you'll reach the end and won't even have realised it.

143560014.review:
Hotline Miami 2 is an amazing sequel to an amazing game that unfortunately many misunderstood.

The first game followed the story of an originally un-named protagonist, only known as "Jacket" as he received random telephone messages that had him "silence" groups of people from the Russian mafia, as he delved deeper and deeper into insanity.

What the second game did was expand on the consequences of his actions and how they affected other people. It consists of multiple characters with different goals and morals existing in the same reality as Jacket did. It tells the story from every perspective, from people who wanted to grab the same 15 minutes of fame, to what was going on inside the mafia, and even Jacket's only friend, who only appeared as a ghost from his past in the original game.

It gives such a thorough look and explanation to an amazing world built my some very talented people. It makes you feel the anguish as you brutally murder thousands of people, just for you to feel the guilt afterwards. It has a lot of metaphores, twists and turns, and send you on an absolute acid trip with probably the best soundtrack ever made in the history of video games.

Personally, this is one of the rare times where a sequel absolutely outdid its predecessor in almost every aspect, and I'm tired of pretending it didn't. The gameplay is smoother, the maps are more unique and bigger (albeit with a difficulty curve), the scope is increased but not dramatically, and delivers one of the most gut-wrenching endings I've ever experienced.

If you've played the first game and are looking for the same action here, you will find it, but please, do this stranger a solid, and listen to the story. You will not regret it.

Here is a video on the game that explains everything way better than I ever could: https://youtu.be/W8PXA2lZf3E

Thanks for reading.

143305102.review:
How are you able to mess up such a simplistic and solid game, HOW?

This game is unbearably awful in absolutely everything that it has to offer.

It spits in the face of everything that made the first game great, while being sluggish, offering a dogshit story and pacing, while being too tight in regards to how difficult it is to play. 

(not in how difficult the game is, and more how difficult it is to PLAY) 

It feels like overstretched DLC. The chapters 16-19 of the first game felt more unique then this entire game. The devs made a lot of upgrades and sacrificed a lot of unique factors from the first game, in return for a more polished looking game, only to create a mediocre experience they don't fully develop on the extent that the first game did. 

Definitely not worth getting

As its level design is way too spacious while not letting you pan out properly on certain maps. This ends up leading to a lot of frustrating deaths due to the enemies seeing you before your sight reaches them. Ex: Swan level 

Alongside these issues, each character story archetype has its own flaws, which truly boil down to a question of skill and if you are able to accomplish these missions while dealing with the limitations. 

But that's the thing, all of these limitations are not fun. 

- Being forced to only use niche masks is not fun
- Being forced into only using melee weapons is not fun
- Being forced to use one gun and not swap in a level with "only dies to gun" foes is not fun


All of these game choices would have been fine, if they weren't forced upon you. Being able to have that freedom of how you approach to finishing a level, was what made every run and rerun in HLM1 so unique. In the second game, you are just forced to play the game the way the devs want you to play the game. You get little to no freedom of choice, which is why I find this game to be a bad continuation to such a solid series.


This game is just not fun, and while I didn't want to do so as I wanted to play this game instead, I think I would much rather prefer grinding out A+ scores on Hotline Miami 1, than play this game ever again. 


If they ever release a Hotline Miami 3, I hope they simply remake the first games mechanics over the ones from this game.

This is an amazing game with one of the best gaming soundtracks I have ever heard. 
It is tough. Very hard at times.

However, the game has a big flaw. Something I did not realize until I tried playing it again many years after first finishing it (and on a different computer). 

I started a new game (in offline mode). Exited after completing three missions. 
Launched the game the next day just to see my progress being lost. So I replayed the missions and made it two more missions in. Then quit the game. 
Launched it the day after. Clicked continue. The game gives me options to choose between all the acts. I have no idea where I was at. 
Decided I had enough of this bullshit and exited the game. 

Why is it that “continue” does not mean “continue from where you left off”? This is honestly a terrible design and I really wish it wasn’t there. It ruins my desire to replay the game.

143273220.review:
This game was a ray of hope in my darkest days.

At 30 years old, I found myself going through a painful separation with my ex-wife, and it left me feeling lost and miserable. I was spiraling out of control and became self-destructive. In a moment of overwhelming emotion, I punched some concrete and severely injured my right hand – the hand that not only worked but also held and carried my children to bed. The hand that was essential for me to continue providing for my family.

Learning the severity of my self-inflicted injury, I sank into a borderline suicidal state. It was a stark contrast from the happiness I experienced just a few months prior, with no history of depression or anxiety. I was in a low spot, unable to see the light on the other side.

During my recovery, I searched for something to occupy my time with my limited abilities. That's when I stumbled upon this game, and although I didn't play it for long, it had a profound impact on me. Even within a day or two of playing, I found a new sense of joy and hope for life. The pain and suffering that enveloped me began to dissipate, and I started appreciating the happiness of others. This game was a brief respite that allowed me to realize that I was going to be okay.

With this newfound realization, I turned off the game and returned to work, enduring the pain in my hand with a newfound motivation. Instead of feeling sorry for myself, I embraced my responsibilities as a father and transformed into the person I needed to be in that moment.

Today, I am on good terms with my children's mother. We have moved past the conflicts and hurtful words, choosing to be parents and friends for the sake of our kids.

Surprisingly, life had another beautiful surprise in store for me. I now have three kids, and my third child is also four years old. I met a woman who went through a similar situation during my separation, and we unexpectedly found each other. Our relationship has blossomed, and we have been together for a year, finding genuine happiness in each other's company.

The moral of my story is simple – you never know what life has in store for you, and giving up when the odds are stacked against you won't lead to the brighter future you deserve. This seemingly insignificant game played a significant role in helping me realize that. Thank you.

142860600.review:
Where do I even begin... this game is worse than it's predecessor in virtually every aspect apart from its graphics and music, which largely remain the same. I fully believe this game would have been universally panned if it wasn't a sequel to, and shared the Hotline Miami name. 

The levels are an absolute slog, lasting far too long with dozens of enemies and large open areas, which require you to play slow and methodical, completely abandoning the previous game's thesis of fast, no-holds barred, reckless beat em' up gameplay. There is absolutely no variety in how the player handles each level and encounter, with little player agency in terms of masks; and said masks give minute gameplay changes. [spoiler]The only major choices you get are in the first half of the game, which to be fair offers some very fun and unique gameplay. This however is extremely underutilized and only lasts for a short while before you are railroaded into specific gameplay encounters. The game would have benefited greatly by allowing the player these options throughout the whole game.[/spoiler] 

I understand wanting to make this game more challenging than the previous, and they do this by adding more enemy types, most of which feel extremely unfair towards the player. For example, there is an enemy which can only be killed using melee weapons, and utilizes a jumping attack to close the distance with the player. This would be fine if said jumping attack didn't clip through doors and walls to latch onto the player, killing them. I didn't have a single death from this enemy which I felt was my fault.

It's mind-boggling to me how utterly broken and unfinished this game feels; almost as if none of the developers actually played it prior to shipping it. Sadly, this game is nothing but a cash grab riding the coattails of the Hotline Miami name.

142148590.review: In a lot of ways, Hotline Miami 2 is an improvement from the original. Most notably, the story. There are many interwoven story lines that are enjoyably intricate, compared to the original's story that mostly took place in the background through subtext. Another benefit of this diversity is the difference in gameplay styles between characters. This was hit or miss, but at least had good variety. However, as you'll glean from a lot of these reviews, levels drag on far longer than they should in some cases. For the first couple acts, I found these reviews to be unfounded, until I found myself in later levels desperately wanting levels to end so I could stop playing but being forced to finish in fear of losing progress. Despite this, I still found myself playing more after the level finished. I found it to be the same reason I find TV to be more palatable than movies.  Having bite size pieces gives the freedom of quitting when you want, even if you end up watching longer than the length of a movie. Levels would drag on for an hour and a half sometimes because of the difficulty level. Overall, this game felt more tedious than its predecessor, but for $2 on sale, I'm glad I played it all the way through and it is definitely a rewarding experience.

It can genuinely make A+ level runs a nightmare sometimes due to the lack of variety in certain situations. 141858706.review:
This game does a ton of things better than the first game, but it does do a few major things worse. I do believe it is still worth buying and playing if you are a fan of the first. It is just important you understand what you are getting yourself into.

First and foremost, hotline Miami 2 has better music, sound design, a better story and I think better characters than the first game. This is a game more ambitious than the first while also staying mostly true to what made the first game great.

However, this game is far harder than the first game and not in a fair way. The levels are much bigger with larger open spaces and it just makes the game unfair. You will die a lot of times by enemies you cannot see because of just how big the open spaces are. Along with that the puzzles aren't as open ended as the first game. Many of the levels have just one path that works to solve the level. The game also mostly does away with the mask mechanic the first game had and this is sad because the masks help bring some variety to the first game. All of these issues can lead to an experience far more frustrating than the first game.

With all this being said it is still a fun game worth your time and I do recommend it at its price tag.

141504923.review:
If you are like me and are getting this game after LOVING the first one, know what you are getting yourself into. This game is [b]HARD[/b]. Not hard like the first one, hard as in constantly dying to enemies off screen and relying on trial and error to get through most levels. The enemy pathing is not consistent between runs either which leads to very unfair and frustrating deaths, even dozens of tries in a particular room. If you are doing your first play though, expect to spend over a long time trying to get through single arenas. 

That being said, the gameplay doesn't need to be fun to be a good game. The music hits hard, the story and atmosphere are very well done (although some aspects are questionable). You can also have close quarter combat through the steam workshop like in the first game.

Oh and the game is like 2 dollars on sale. Don't lie to yourself. You've spent more on less.

140863969.review: The well known sequel to the famous Hotline Miami, which with its graphical style and also amazing music creating a unique atmosphere, is unfortunately not a game I can recommend to anyone. I am really sorry to write this, but apart from the interesting twists and improvements to the mechanics themselves, this game simply discourages people from playing it because of the very poorly designed maps and completely random bugs, which were absent in the first game (or I didn't come across them). The problems are several: the maps are so big that even moving the camera with shift as far as you can, you still won't see the enemies that see you. For almost the entire game you have to hold shift to see what is happening in front of you at all. If you want to get high ranks for missions then you will have to learn dozens (if not hundreds) of invisible enemies. This is more than a waste of time. The game decides to take away all your freedom to solve maps the way you want and forces you to play a specific way (you have no choice of masks, most missions are impossible to play without firearms). Terrible bugs with doors that make enemies sometimes become immortal in them, and larger enemies as they walk into you in a doorway start behaving strangely, shooting blindly and losing ammo to nothing. The crappy map design was decided to be clogged up with whole armies of enemies, which makes this game even more of a no-brainer, and if you enjoyed playing with any tactics before, that's gone here. You have to learn to play a certain way, learn the position of enemies invisible to your camera, force yourself to play with firearms and try not to swear as a random bug spoils your game. With a lot of respect for the first game, I completed Hotline Miami 2. The characters, animations and graphics are cool. The music creates a very good atmosphere. The plot was... just weird, but that fits the atmosphere of the game. Still, I felt like this game was made by absolutely different people. The game lends itself to a one-time pass and there is nothing to come back to again, unfortunately. I prefer to remember later that it was quite fun to play, instead of remembering the large number of bugs and the incredibly badly made maps.

140595435.review:
I tenatively recommend this game. I enjoyed the first half of it, but by the end of act  3 I was really starting to feel burnt out, and I just can't bring myself to care enough to finish the final act.

Obviously, this review is oriented more toward casual players on their first or second playthroughs, not hardcore players/speedrunners. 

Things I liked about this game:

Weapon and mask variety has increased, and there are some fun new secrets to explore.

The level editor is great, allowing endless replay value if that's your thing.

The soundtrack and art fucking SLAP.

The story is really good!

Things I don't like:

Enemies react a lot faster than in HLM1, so it's less about improvising on the fly and more about frame-perfect memorization of enemy spawns.  AI is also pretty inconsistent across the board. They're generally pretty predictable, until they're not.  The way enemies react to gunfire is the biggest and most obvious chip in the AI's armor. They either hear you from across the map when they should have no way of knowing you're there, or you can fire a magazine on the other side of the wall without drawing any enemies, which can actually be a bad thing depending on your strategy for the level.

Knives no longer 1-hit kill when thrown to make way for one of the mask powers, which I think is really lame, I don't see why they couldn't co-exist.

Door physics are still jank as hell.

Beard levels are extremely unfun and tedious to play through, and pretty much neutered my drive to keep playing. Everything about their layout and the mechanics behind picking up ammo slow the game to a crawl.

Level design in general has had a pretty significant downgrade from HLM1. Cheap deathtraps and long corridors that you can't see to the end of but can still be shot from. Less secrets and fun things to discover, lots of cheap spawnpoints that can kill you before you've oriented yourself with the playspace, individual stages of levels are now on average about 3 times as long as they were in HLM1, meaning that you get sent back a LOT further on death, making this way more frustrating than the first title when considering all of the other level design quirks.

Conclusion:

Hotline Miami 2 has a lot going for it if it's your type of game. It sacrificed pretty much all of HLM1's accessibility and flexibility to commit to the "speedrunner" style of play, but if you're up for a grind then there's a lot of good stuff to unpack underneath.

Personally, I think it's less fun than HLM1, but still worth trying out. If it's not your thing, maybe just look up a story analysis and the OST separately.

140163544.review:
I've heard a lot of people complain about this game, and I can't really see why. Apart from a few minor issues, this game is nothing short of a masterpiece.

The graphics. Most people know to not judge a game too much by it's graphics, and this game is a prime example. Some people may see the simple graphics and get turned off by it, however there's a difference between "good" graphics and a good artstyle. Hotline Miami has a great and consistent artstyle throughout. The retro aesthetic is a great fit for a game set in the 80s and early 90s, especially for Hotline Miami. The graphics never feel off, and if anything improve the experience.

The soundtrack. I'll keep this point brief, considering everyone already knows how good this soundtrack is. If you somehow don't, well, it's amazing. Every soundtrack hits home and fits the atmosphere perfectly. Everyone who worked on this game's soundtrack deserve an award.

The difficulty. Hotline Miami 2 handles map design a lot differently than 1. Maps are more open, and there are a lot more people. Sightlines are often long, meaning you can easily be shot from off-screen. This has led to a lot of frustration among players, and understandably so. It's quite frustrating to be shot from off-screen where you can't see an enemy, however it's not something that ruins the game for me. I still think the map design is largely a step up from Hotline Miami 1. With time, you learn where enemies are and come from, making the process of clearing maps smoother. In addition, Hotline Miami 1 in most cases allowed you to pick from a large array of masks, some of which were quite overpowered. In Hotline Miami 2, you rarely get the option to use special abilities, in turn making the game slightly harder.

The gameplay is fun and fast paced, just like the predecessor. However I would argue the overall feel of the game has been improved, since the gameplay is less janky and bugs are much less of a problem. The gameplay is much more refined, whereas in the first game it felt a bit more loose. Though if you want to give Hotline Miami a go, but don't want the intense difficulty of the second game, I can still recommend the first one. It's still very fun, while not as challenging, though do be warned about bugs. As mentioned, the first game is a lot more prone to jank than the second.

The story is in my opinion, really good. It's expertly crafted and told brilliantly. Arguably the best part is that it's completely optional. The story is there if you want it, but you can simply ignore and/or skip all pieces of dialogue altogether if you simply want to get straight to the gunplay. Either way it's a great addition for obvious reasons.

I highly recommend both these games. However if you plan on playing both, I recommend playing the first one first. Either way, it's a great game and I thank Dennaton for bringing us these two masterpieces.

*Reupload

139879751.review:
Gone was the expert level design of the first game. Now, the levels are long and big, easily overstaying their welcome. The amount of cheap deaths to enemies off-screen is simply endless. And it's frustrating. Sometimes, there is no way to know that you're within an enemy's line of sight, not even with shift view. The color palette of some levels is horrible. Completely white, whiplashing with the crosshair. I lost count of how many times I lost track of the crosshair during those levels.

Gone was the balanced enemy number per floor. Now, floors are littered with so many enemies that attempting a fast-paced run can easily result in a cheap death. Their AI is somehow worse than of its predecessor. Sometimes, they're blind, sometimes, they have sixth sense. Their behavior is just inconsistent.

Gone was the dance of death, high-octane gameplay structure of the first game. Now, it forces a more tactical approach, because trying the aggressive, fast-paced approach of the first game is practically impossible, considering the amount of enemies per area. Dying a cheap death in a floor after wasting so much time cautiously killing them creates no incentive to hit 'R' and try again with a bigger determination like its predecessor, it just creates incentive to hit the ESC, quit this piece of crap game and uninstall it. Seriously, baiting enemies into a corner to kill their dumbasses is not fun. I refuse to believe that Dennaton actually playtested this game.

Gone was the simplistic yet flexible mask selection that allows you to have perks and skills. Now, you're restricted to what the game wants you to use in a sort of loadout system. It's boring, it gives the player no freedom and completely restricts any creative approach.

And gone was the sense of catharsis and gratification the first game gave us after completing a chapter. Now it's just "finally dealt with this bs".

The story is surprisingly engrossing and the soundtrack slaps (honestly, I wanted to hear a Perturbator music while playing a kickass game, not this garbage). Those are the only positives I can say about Hotline Miami 2.

This game is not only disappointing, it's also a piece of trash. It's a hollow shell of what Hotline Miami once was. And that's just sad...

But honestly, to Dennaton's credit, you can see they really tried to make a worthy sequel, not  a soulless cash grab, and I respect their passion and attempt. It's just that perhaps they were way too ambitious for what their engine and design of the first game allowed them to reproduce successfully. Their approach was clearly the "bigger is better", but that's not always a recipe for success.

A sequel everyone needed from a classic.
The whole idea of playing with multiple characters other than Jacket and Rider feels so good, especially since each one has a specific playing style and ways to knock-down enemies.
And the music... Oh, the music. They took the songs for each level and cutscene to heart, making sure every scene feels like you're invincible.
The campain is longer than the first game, and has a hard mode when you finish the normal difficulty. After beating both, you can also try user-made levels/campains, or create one yourself; I haven't touched it, but it seems to have a lot of potential due to the possibility to make custom sprites.
I enjoyed every weapon and character, would recommend playing.

Now, for the achivements:
Mostly similiar to the prequel: Combo achievements, Challenge achievements, a Collectible achivement, the A+ achievement, and so on. You won't have any problems until you reach the last 2, which are the Collect All achievement and Genocide (Kill 50000 enemies); even after finishing campaing on normal, retrying it to get A+ on all levels, and doing it on hard mode, I still only got 17k kills and had to farm the rest.
